body: It would be great if we can run spark 2.3, since that is the first official version supporting kubernetes deployment and we already have a couple of kubernetes clusters in production already.
It happens when you use the Hoodie client to upsert against existing datasets.

Gave a quick shot. Seeing some unit test failures around netty. Have to take a another pass. 

In the meantime, would building against 2.3.0 yourself work for you as a stop gap?
@n3nash: Addressed review comments. Please take a pass

Thanks for the investigation, @vinothchandar .
I am fine with forking the repo and doing it by myself. Just want to make sure not to get too far away from the official implementation in the future. 
This ticket is more or less asking about spark version support strategy of hudi, so I will get a better idea how much maintenance effort there will be for us if building against spark 2.3.0 by myself.
@xjodoin Setting `SparkSession.builder().config("spark.serializer", "org.apache.spark.serializer.KryoSerializer")` resolved this issue for me. The `HoodieDataFile` seems to be only kyro SerDe-able.

For this we will need to have the accumulator passed from the HoodieWriteClient down to the IO handles. I intend to make this change very soon and filed a task for this : https://github.com/uber/hudi/issues/384. Till then, adding the metrics to PerfStat. The diff is updated, please take another pass.

This one seems tricky as Java Annotations (used by spring-shell) is limited in flexibility (no inheritance, only static attribute values at call-site). The only way I can think of is using Annotation Processor to generate wrapper methods on the fly. I will sync up with you in person to discuss this.

@vinothchandar @bvaradar

@n3nash: We should address the redundant fs.listStatus calls so that we no longer have to worry about working around it. 

As we have MVCC, can we construct FileSystemView only once in the driver and make it available as a spark broadcast read-only object.  For FileSystemView lookup, this view should be the correct one. 
But for the sake of defining the view in a general sense similar to DB transaction,  At any point in ingestion:  the real view of the file-system as seen by ingestion process should be the merged view of this broadcast variable (initial view) and a delta-view (from WriteStatus results) which the ingestion itself caused by adding new file-slices or adding new log-files to latest-file-slice. 
 
For the Reader, it should only be the initial file-system-view. For Async ingestion, this is similar to that of  ingestion (merged view of this broadcast variable (initial-view) and a delta-view which the compactor itself caused by compacting part of latest file-slice).

@bvaradar Thanks for your comments. I agree with you that we have to address fs.listStatus once so we don't have to worry about it all the time. This has been a topic of discussion for a very long time, you can also see a PR made along these lines here : https://github.com/uber/hudi/pull/278. There are different possible approaches and trade-offs which we have discussed internally. Happy to share the approaches and trade-offs offline if you're interested. We also want to add this : https://github.com/uber/hudi/issues/209 when we make that change.
The purpose of this PR might be limited to just global index. We shuld file another task for listStatus() optimizations and prioritize that sometime soon.

@suniluber Any updates on this ?

Structured streaming integration is on the roadmap & the ultimate goal. Few issues to iron out before that - async compaction & sending inserts to log files

#261  tracks it.. for now, you can try running small batches. does that work?

@n3nash @vinothchandar @ovj @bvaradar @jianxu
I tested the changes for GC issues.

I ingested about 7.5 million records in a single parquet file of size 1G
I then generated 20K deletion messages and about 5 million new messages and ingested.
This updated the 20K records and created new 1G file and created a 2nd file for the inserts. Did not observe any significant changes for GC times.

Thanks for the reply @vinothchandar. I was doing exactly what is described in #261 but was worrying about getting deviated from the official code further and further if I stay on my own fork. 

And also wondering if those few issues mentioned above are the blockers for the structured streaming, or just higher priority on the list than structured streaming?
undo #389

Here is a summary from my investigation. We dont use the commitTime in HoodieRecordLocation in a way that matters. That's why it works now . 

HBaseIndex could in theory list and find out the commitTime once and we can annotate stuff nicely. But given fast path is already not relying on this. I am willing to concede. Filed an issue to track this

Contribution would be great. No, they are not blockers per se. They just lower latencies down to streaming levels , without them each batch may still take few mins depending on your workload. 

Would be thrilled to get a patch to support sturcutured streaming :)

@n3nash : Updated PR and also left some comments. Thanks

I think what you want is the KEEP_LATEST_FILE_VERSIONS policy, which retains upto X versions per file (group). Default is KEEP_LATEST_COMMITS which retains X commits worth of data for incremental consumption. For your case, you might also want to set `hoodie.cleaner.policy` to the right policy 

In any case, just having 1 version of the file means, the queries could fail a lot more as you clean/delete older files (hive queries for e.g take a while to run, and they could be still planning to read older versions) and thats why we atleast try to retain few versions in practice.

https://uber.github.io/hudi/dev_setup.html covers devsetup. 
I don't think we have a similar PR for this. So far, just scoped teh task down :)

@vinothchandar

Did a micro-benchmark by generating a file slice as follows 
- 400MB base file with 18M records
- Each record has 20 fields or so. Lots of nulls
- Log file has equal 18M updates. 
- We test reading upto 50% or 8.9M records from log. 

Using vmtouch to control caching of files on linux.. Here's how the numbers stack up.  

| Operation       | Fully Cached  | Zero Cache  |
 | ----------------|:-------------:| -----------:|
 | RawLogBytesRead | 1722ms        | 7417ms      |
 | LogBlockRead (metadata) | 633ms        | 612ms      |
 | LogBlockRead (data) | 19324ms         |   22567ms   |
 | ParquetRead (key/best) | 11358ms        | 12232ms      |
 | ParquetRead (full record/worst) | 18930ms        | 20103ms      |

With caching there are good gains when I/O is the actual bottleneck.. Once we get into log reading or parquet processing, its mostly CPU and thus there is smaller gains from caching itself.

Hey. thanks for a taking a look at the deltastreamer.
On Parquet: 
 - Its currently is ingestion centric, thats probably why it does not support parquet yet... 
 - if you are looking to just do a one-time parquet import, the `HDFSParquetImporter` could help. There is a CLI command.. 
 - you can always just use the datasource and wrap it in your own Spark job. 

Actually there is planned work to rework the deltastreamer to simply use Spark data source API and move away from RDD level APIs it uses. That should fix most of your first two issues.. How hard is it for you to try the datasource api in the mean time? Longer term, we are planning integrations with Apache Gobblin and also uber's own ingestion system would be open sourced soon - which will work with Hoodie out-of-box. (again none of these support Parquet source, since users mostly write their own spark jobs for etls)..

Also adding in the other issue you reported.. 

```


    Trying to change the source-format by adding the option --source-format AVRO always throws an Exception for me:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException at com.beust.jcommander.JCommander.convertValue(JCommander.java:1305) at com.beust.jcommander.JCommander.convertValue(JCommander.java:1228) ... at com.uber.hoodie.utilities.deltastreamer.HoodieDeltaStreamer.main(HoodieDeltaStreamer.java:415)
```

DeltaStreamer is a modified version of the tool we have internally. We have used it on our clusters/environment successfully (don't quite recall whether the files were picked up from HDFS or localFS etc)..

Let me check out these issues.. I responded on the other ticket on parquet support.
Closing this. Please reopen this or new one for followup.
